claim: The Eiffel tower was used as a symbol of the French Revolution.

supporting.text: The Eiffel Tower was completed in 1889, nearly a century after the French Revolution (1789–1799), making it impossible to have been a symbol of the event.

attacks.text: The Eiffel Tower was completed in 1889, nearly a century after the French Revolution (1789–1799), making it impossible to have been a symbol of the event.
Symbols can be retroactively associated with historical events, even if they were built later.
The Eiffel Tower was built as part of the 1889 World's Fair, not to commemorate the French Revolution.
Later artistic or political movements may have repurposed the Eiffel Tower as a symbol of revolutionary ideals.

supporting.text: The French Revolution's symbols included the tricolor flag, the Phrygian cap, and the Bastille, none of which are architecturally related to the Eiffel Tower.

attacks.text: The French Revolution's symbols included the tricolor flag, the Phrygian cap, and the Bastille, none of which are architecturally related to the Eiffel Tower.
The Eiffel Tower was built in 1889, long after the French Revolution (1789–1799), making it impossible to be a symbol of the Revolution.
The Eiffel Tower was later adopted as a symbol of French national pride, which could be loosely associated with the ideals of the Revolution.
Symbolic associations can evolve over time, but this does not mean the Eiffel Tower was ever a direct symbol of the Revolution itself.

supporting.text: The Eiffel Tower was built for the 1889 Exposition Universelle as a celebration of industrial progress, not as a commemoration of the French Revolution.

attacks.text: The Eiffel Tower was built for the 1889 Exposition Universelle as a celebration of industrial progress, not as a commemoration of the French Revolution.
The French Revolution was a key historical event that shaped modern France, and the Eiffel Tower, as a national symbol, indirectly represents its legacy.
The Eiffel Tower was explicitly designed to showcase France's industrial achievements, with no documented intent to symbolize the French Revolution.
National symbols often evolve in meaning over time, and the Eiffel Tower may have later been associated with the French Revolution by popular culture.
Official historical records and Gustave Eiffel's own writings confirm the tower's purpose was purely technological and celebratory of the Exposition Universelle.

supporting.text: Historical records and contemporary accounts of the French Revolution do not mention the Eiffel Tower, as it did not exist at the time.

attacks.text: Historical records and contemporary accounts of the French Revolution do not mention the Eiffel Tower, as it did not exist at the time.
The Eiffel Tower was built in 1889, nearly a century after the French Revolution, making it impossible to be a symbol of the event.
Some modern interpretations might symbolically associate the Eiffel Tower with the ideals of the French Revolution, such as liberty and progress.
Symbolic associations are not equivalent to historical usage, and there is no evidence that the Eiffel Tower was ever intended to represent the French Revolution.

supporting.text: The design and construction of the Eiffel Tower were led by Gustave Eiffel, who was born in 1832, long after the French Revolution had ended.

attacks.text: The design and construction of the Eiffel Tower were led by Gustave Eiffel, who was born in 1832, long after the French Revolution had ended.
The Eiffel Tower was built in 1889, during the centennial celebration of the French Revolution, and was intended to symbolize the revolution's ideals.
While the Eiffel Tower was built later, its design and purpose were influenced by the revolutionary spirit and technological progress associated with the French Revolution.
Gustave Eiffel himself was inspired by the revolutionary ideals, and the tower's construction was seen as a continuation of the revolution's legacy.
